Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Nucleic acid circuitry for programming gene expression

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
0954566
Seelig

The proposed work will enable a potentially transformative technology for controlling cellular behavior using nucleic acids. The PI will engineer synthetic molecular circuitry that can analyze RNA expression inside living cells and { based on this analysis { autonomously control gene expression. The PI will show that nucleic acid circuitry can distinguish between di_erent cell types and states and can specifically regulate a target gene only in a subset of cells. A central aim of this project is to increase the specificity of conventional antisense and siRNA-based therapeutics by combining drug delivery with sensing and logic. Specific research objectives are: (i) The design of hybridization-based molecular sensors for the detection of RNA in living cells; (ii) the design of controllable molecular actuators based on antisense oligonucleotides and silencing RNA; (iii) the construction of integrated sensor-actuator systems for conditional gene regulation. This program provides the basis for the construction of complex multi-component circuits for programmable control of gene expression. This work will lead to new molecular tools for temporal and spatial control of gene expression, with the potential for wide-spread applications in disease therapy and in basic biology research. The proposed research is tightly integrated with an outreach program with two main aims. The first aim is to develop an educational framework that teaches the interdisciplinary skills required to succeed in synthetic biology research. The second aim is to leverage this framework to attract and engage students who are not traditionally involved with life-science research, or would not consider enrolling in one of the traditional tracks in an electrical engineering or computer science program (the PI's home departments are EE and CS).

POR.DRECONTENT:
A major hurdle for the de novo design of synthetic gene circuits in mammalian cells is that we generally do not fully understand how the sequence of a cis-regulatory elements --- promoters, enhancers, untranslated regions, splice regulatory regions and more --- relate to their function. In the absence of a well-characterized sequence-function relationship it is challenging to predictably modulate gene expression in synthetic constructs or to reliably predict how endogenous genes are expressed. In work supported through this CAREER Award, we addressed this challenge and asked how local sequence information determines the alternative splicing patterns of genes and therefore the relative abundances of protein isoforms. We combined synthetic biology, massively parallel functional measurement, and machine learning towards assaying and modeling the alternative isoform patterns of over 2 Million synthetic mini-genes. When applied to the human genome, our model, which was trained only on synthetic sequences, accurately predicted changes in human isoform levels caused by single nucleotide polymorphisms both within splice donors and in surrounding intronic sequences. Our results provide a comprehensive picture of the sequence determinants of isoform abundance in alternative splicing, while also demonstrating a novel, broadly applicable approach for empirically learning models of sequence-function relationships.

A second hurdle to achieving precise control of mammalian transgene expression is that protein expression levels remain susceptible to fluctuations (noise) and external perturbations. Developing methods for minimizing such variability is a key challenge if we are to make progress towards the rational design of reliable synthetic gene circuits. In work supported through this award we demonstrated that precise control over protein synthesis could be achieved in a minimal autoregulatory gene circuit consisting of an intronic miRNA that targets its own transcript. This work demonstrated a broadly useful mechanism for long-term stable expression of engineered genetic programs in mammalian cells.

This awards supported participation in the BRIDGE program organized by the Engineering Advising and Diversity Center (EADC) in the college of engineering at the University of Washington. Every summer, around 30-40 incoming UW women and underrepresented minority freshman and transfer students attend a four-week workshop at UW. As part of the BRIDGE program, students take workshops in core engineering courses, work in a research laboratory with a faculty member, familiarize themselves with the University, and establish a network of friends and contacts.
